title: SECURITY: Referencing  previous Reports attachment_IDs on new Reports via Draft_Sync DELETES Attachments

activities.message:
As a continuing POC if I create a new report via Draft_Sync and set as seen in the above screenshot the parameteer report[attachment_IDs][]=79192 the above attachment F79192 will be deleted from report #123615

Thanks! Let me know if you need any additional info in address this!
activities.markdown_message:
As a continuing POC if I create a new report via Draft_Sync and set as seen in the above screenshot the parameteer report[attachment_IDs][]=79192 the above attachment deletepoc.png (F79192) will be deleted from report #123615

Thanks! Let me know if you need any additional info in address this!

Thanks,

Willian

I can delete all of my attachments by referencing them through a single draft sync

The attachment in report #████ has been deleted by issuing a draft_sync on hackerone.com/security/reports/draft_sync
The security attachment in report #████ has been deleted by issuing a draft_sync on hackerone.com/security/reports/draft_sync


Is this intentional?

Cause as far as I know, you cant delete attachments from reports after they have been submitted (even days before)

Sorry, I misunderstood the issue.

If you are able to remove an arbitrary attachment from any report, it would, of course, be a security vulnerability.

activities.message:
Hi @nismo,

I've confirmed that this only works when the reports belong to the same user (you). While this could get annoying for teams to have attachments disappear, can you write back with your thoughts on the security implications of this?

Happy Hacking!
Fern :)
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @nismo,

I've confirmed that this only works when the reports belong to the same user (you). While this could get annoying for teams to have attachments disappear, can you write back with your thoughts on the security implications of this?

Happy Hacking!
Fern :)

activities.message:
Dear @fern 

Based on Risk Assessment principles, Security is based of the triangle CIA (Confidentiality, Integrity, Availability). With its new feature HackerOne added a unique reference (ID) to each and every attachment ever submitted to HackerOne (even if hosted in Amazon S3). 

So:

***ATTACHMENT_ID is a serialized counter***
1. You can now know the number of attachments submitted to HackerOne (79192 attachments till #123615 meaning this very report)
2. If you create any report (even a ReportDraft before submit a real case) you can see the attachment_ID after a successful upload. The Attachment_ID is not a random number but a counter which adds 1, each time you upload something.
ex. 
a. You upload a file - Counter in 70001 so the attachment_ID is 70001
b. Another user (B) in Hacker One uploads a file - He gets ID of 70002
c. If you delete your initial file and upload it again you will get ID 70003 (so you now know that another user has already uploaded an attachment (step b)
Perhaps this should not be serialized (but this should just be an informative suggestion)

***TEAMS reward then fix later*** or ***TEAMS ask for attachments***
Many Teams due to high submission choose to ask for POC (pics of video) then validate a POC, reward and then fix after time. They even ask for attachments in clarification by choosing the flag *Needs more Info* (which also reduces a point in reputation)

By using the technique (security bug) shown in this report, a user can show the POC, get rewarded and then if he deletes the attachments, the Team will be blind in fixing the Vulnerability reported since there will be no attachments to help them  (Not polite, but HackeOne must enforce policy to not let the user do so)

*This directly attacks Integrity and Availability of HACKERONE, since by deleted those attachments, leaves the fix dpt of TEAM unable to reevaluate and assess the problem*

_So this not a simple annoyance, because you are NOT deleting the Reference BUT THE ENTIRE attachment_

***PUBLIC DISCLOSED reports***
If a user does not agree on public disclosure, this will be enforced after a period of 30 days. By using this method (security bug) the user deletes all attachments and therefore the final report is not well understood by the reviewers(which is also a valuable asset in the HackeOne and Security Community. It raises Security Awareness .
Even Teams have no control to what just happened (lack of attachments), and this will also be visible to public viewers since a H1 account is not required to see or index the vulnerability reports made public.

*This is also an attack to Integrity and Availability of HACKERONE*

From the above, my initial and main concern is that HACKERONE created a public direct reference counter to attachments, making our life easier in creating quality reports easier and also TEAMS reviewing process more readable and understandable but inserted a  bug in the implementation of it (Hitting INTEGRITY AND AVAILABILITY of attachments), rather than a simple annoyance bug.

Since Integrity and Availability are two sides in the CIA triangle, this is considered broken and therefore this is a SECURITY BUG rather that annoyance, needed to be fixed, as soon as possible to make the attachment process robust as before and very useful (as it is with reference),

I do appreciate that you did evaluate the POC and confirmed each step and point (like reports have to be from the same reporter).

I dont know if this works to delete entire Team attachments if you are a member of a Team, cause I dont belong or have a Team. Perhaps you can do this

Hope you will fix this!

Once more, thanks for your time reading this!

Based on Risk Assessment principles, Security is based of the triangle CIA (Confidentiality, Integrity, Availability). With its new feature HackerOne added a unique reference (ID) to each and every attachment ever submitted to HackerOne (even if hosted in Amazon S3).

So:

ATTACHMENT_ID is a serialized counter

  1. You can now know the number of attachments submitted to HackerOne (79192 attachments till #123615 meaning this very report)
  2. If you create any report (even a ReportDraft before submit a real case) you can see the attachment_ID after a successful upload. The Attachment_ID is not a random number but a counter which adds 1, each time you upload something. ex. a. You upload a file - Counter in 70001 so the attachment_ID is 70001 b. Another user (B) in Hacker One uploads a file - He gets ID of 70002 c. If you delete your initial file and upload it again you will get ID 70003 (so you now know that another user has already uploaded an attachment (step b) Perhaps this should not be serialized (but this should just be an informative suggestion)

TEAMS reward then fix later or TEAMS ask for attachments
Many Teams due to high submission choose to ask for POC (pics of video) then validate a POC, reward and then fix after time. They even ask for attachments in clarification by choosing the flag Needs more Info (which also reduces a point in reputation)

By using the technique (security bug) shown in this report, a user can show the POC, get rewarded and then if he deletes the attachments, the Team will be blind in fixing the Vulnerability reported since there will be no attachments to help them (Not polite, but HackeOne must enforce policy to not let the user do so)

This directly attacks Integrity and Availability of HACKERONE, since by deleted those attachments, leaves the fix dpt of TEAM unable to reevaluate and assess the problem

So this not a simple annoyance, because you are NOT deleting the Reference BUT THE ENTIRE attachment

PUBLIC DISCLOSED reports
If a user does not agree on public disclosure, this will be enforced after a period of 30 days. By using this method (security bug) the user deletes all attachments and therefore the final report is not well understood by the reviewers(which is also a valuable asset in the HackeOne and Security Community. It raises Security Awareness .
Even Teams have no control to what just happened (lack of attachments), and this will also be visible to public viewers since a H1 account is not required to see or index the vulnerability reports made public.

This is also an attack to Integrity and Availability of HACKERONE

From the above, my initial and main concern is that HACKERONE created a public direct reference counter to attachments, making our life easier in creating quality reports easier and also TEAMS reviewing process more readable and understandable but inserted a bug in the implementation of it (Hitting INTEGRITY AND AVAILABILITY of attachments), rather than a simple annoyance bug.

Since Integrity and Availability are two sides in the CIA triangle, this is considered broken and therefore this is a SECURITY BUG rather that annoyance, needed to be fixed, as soon as possible to make the attachment process robust as before and very useful (as it is with reference),

I do appreciate that you did evaluate the POC and confirmed each step and point (like reports have to be from the same reporter).

I dont know if this works to delete entire Team attachments if you are a member of a Team, cause I dont belong or have a Team. Perhaps you can do this

Hope you will fix this!

Once more, thanks for your time reading this!

activities.message:
Hi @fern 

I can confirm that I can no longer delete attachments from previous reports, which means that the fix is working.

Meanwhile, please check the following:

1. Create a new report and Upload an attachment and check its attachment_id (for ex. 81295)
2. Delete the attachment and never file that report.
3. Create a new report (even for a different company) and by using the method stated in  this report, insert the attachment_id (81295) in a new report.
4. You will see that the attachment exists! and you will see the reference and the name.

Anyway,  thanks again for fixing the initial deleting attachments from previous reports!

Great work!

Thanks!
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @fern

I can confirm that I can no longer delete attachments from previous reports, which means that the fix is working.

Meanwhile, please check the following:

  1. Create a new report and Upload an attachment and check its attachment_id (for ex. 81295)
  2. Delete the attachment and never file that report.
  3. Create a new report (even for a different company) and by using the method stated in this report, insert the attachment_id (81295) in a new report.
  4. You will see that the attachment exists! and you will see the reference and the name.

Anyway, thanks again for fixing the initial deleting attachments from previous reports!

Great work!

Thanks!

activities.message:
Hi @nismo,

Thanks again for you report and I'm glad we resolved that.

Regarding your latest odd behaviour, thanks for bringing it up. However, since in the newest case, these are attachments that have never been attached to a report that is submitted, we don't believe there are any security implications to this.
You can still only access your own attachments, and once they have become attached to a report, there is no "going back" and removing them anymore. As you are still the owner of the attachment and cannot attach others' files to your own reports, this is not a security concern.
In that case, it would be more of a functional quirk which usually goes to support@hackerone.com.

Happy Hacking!
Fern :)
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @nismo,

Thanks again for you report and I'm glad we resolved that.

Regarding your latest odd behaviour, thanks for bringing it up. However, since in the newest case, these are attachments that have never been attached to a report that is submitted, we don't believe there are any security implications to this.
You can still only access your own attachments, and once they have become attached to a report, there is no "going back" and removing them anymore. As you are still the owner of the attachment and cannot attach others' files to your own reports, this is not a security concern.
In that case, it would be more of a functional quirk which usually goes to support@hackerone.com.

Happy Hacking!
Fern :)

activities.message:
@fern 

The above method explained above does not require a report to be filed in order to work. Just an attachment to be uploaded and therefore to assign it get a unique attachment_id.
You can reference it in any of your later reports (as long as you never used it before).

The latest behavior was just a rule of thumb that what goes up on the Internet, stays on the Internet.

Anyway thanks for fixing this security vulnerability and I am also glad we resolved it!  Great work!

Thanks!
activities.markdown_message:
@fern

The above method explained above does not require a report to be filed in order to work. Just an attachment to be uploaded and therefore to assign it get a unique attachment_id.
You can reference it in any of your later reports (as long as you never used it before).

The latest behavior was just a rule of thumb that what goes up on the Internet, stays on the Internet.

Anyway thanks for fixing this security vulnerability and I am also glad we resolved it! Great work!

Thanks!

activities.message:
Hi @nismo,
Yes, we understand regarding the attachments. However, the attachments you are uploading still belong to you. If they have been unused, you can still attach them to any new report you are filing. We do not consider this to be a vulnerability because you are still the owner of the (unattached) attachment. 
This is because once you attach an unused attachment to a report submission, it no longer becomes "unused" and at that point, you can no longer remove attachments or switch them around.

Hope this clarifies things.

Fern:)
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @nismo,
Yes, we understand regarding the attachments. However, the attachments you are uploading still belong to you. If they have been unused, you can still attach them to any new report you are filing. We do not consider this to be a vulnerability because you are still the owner of the (unattached) attachment.
This is because once you attach an unused attachment to a report submission, it no longer becomes "unused" and at that point, you can no longer remove attachments or switch them around.

Hope this clarifies things.

Fern:)

activities.message:
@fern

Glad we agree!

As you know, before introducing the attachment_ID it was impossible to reference an uploaded attachment if you delete it via ***X*** button.
At least with attachment_id you can reference it, whenever you want!
Of course I am not claiming vulnerability on the above situation, thats why I referenced it here for information purposes and has nothing to do with the initial report which was INDEED a vulnerability and I am glad you fixed it!.

Thanks for your help again!

activities.markdown_message:
Hey @nismo,

Sorry, we still haven't made a final decision. We'll let you know as soon as we have. Please bear with us just a little bit longer. We appreciate your patience.

@siebejan

No problem. I was just wondering since I understood that you had agreed that this was a security issue and that a decision had been made.

I will be waiting. Thanks!

@nismo, thanks for the report.

While this issue only lets you remove attachments from your own reports, this could be used to remove attachments from existing reports that a team needs. This goes against the spirit of how we treat attachments, and such, we are awarding our minimum bounty for an "interesting" issue.

Happy hacking!

activities.message: Sorry that it took us a while to understand what you were trying to convey originally. We'll try to do better in the future.

activities.message:
@reed @dirk 

I dont know If I should also report the following concerning your new attachment reference system in here or as a new case so please advise.

***Case***
Reference system (assigning numbers) in Attachments only works in initial report comment and not on later comments.

******
This means that when a user drafts a new report only the initial attached files get a reference number. If a user writes or reply with  new comment and uploads a new attachment, this does not get a reference number.

This shouldn't happen since the Reference Number is FXXYYY and it points to
https://hackerone-attachments.s3.amazonaws.com/production/000/0XX/YYY/etc... as you may see in the page code.

Also, If you upload a new attachment although this goes to
https://hackerone-attachments.s3.amazonaws.com/production/000/0AB/CDE/etc as the above attachments, it does not get an attachment number (For example ABCDE) and you cant reference it inline or as a link and of course _you cant do that in comments and report summary_ as HackerOne states in https://support.hackerone.com/hc/en-us/articles/207715363

Hope this will be fixed also!
activities.markdown_message:
@reed @dirk

I dont know If I should also report the following concerning your new attachment reference system in here or as a new case so please advise.

Case
Reference system (assigning numbers) in Attachments only works in initial report comment and not on later comments.

This means that when a user drafts a new report only the initial attached files get a reference number. If a user writes or reply with new comment and uploads a new attachment, this does not get a reference number.

This shouldn't happen since the Reference Number is FXXYYY and it points to
https://hackerone-attachments.s3.amazonaws.com/production/000/0XX/YYY/etc... as you may see in the page code.

Also, If you upload a new attachment although this goes to
https://hackerone-attachments.s3.amazonaws.com/production/000/0AB/CDE/etc as the above attachments, it does not get an attachment number (For example ABCDE) and you cant reference it inline or as a link and of course you cant do that in comments and report summary as HackerOne states in https://support.hackerone.com/hc/en-us/articles/207715363

Hope this will be fixed also!

activities.message: @nismo, please file new security issues as separate reports. If it's not a security issue, you can use https://support.hackerone.com/hc/en-us/requests/new to submit a support ticket.
activities.markdown_message: @nismo, please file new security issues as separate reports. If it's not a security issue, you can use https://support.hackerone.com/hc/en-us/requests/new to submit a support ticket.

activities.message: Thanks! I have already submitted a support ticket for the above functionality!
activities.markdown_message: Thanks! I have already submitted a support ticket for the above functionality!

vulnerability_information_html:
Issue
New HackerOne exciting addition is the ability to include inline images by using their reference_ID, which is in this case {Fxxxxx}. The reference ID is bind to the its report Context_ID and cant be referenced by others (unique reference

Is seems that if the reference_ID is used in another newest report the attachment is deleted from the original report

Note: Reports must belong to the same reporter

POC

  1. Create a Report with an attachment and file it to any team. Notice the reference_ID (Fxxxxx)
  2. Create a new Report for any team and reference the ID via a POST in draft_Sync POST /security/reports/draft_sync HTTP/1.1 As soon as you do the POST Go to the https://hackeone/security/reports/new You will see the reference_ID attachment attached.
  3. Go to the report in 1. The reference_ID and attachment is deleted for the original report!

Hope it will be fixed!

Thanks!
vulnerability_information:
***Issue***
New HackerOne exciting addition is the ability to include inline images by using their reference_ID, which is in this case {Fxxxxx}. The reference ID is bind to the its report Context_ID and cant be referenced by others (unique reference

Is seems that if the reference_ID is used in another newest report the attachment is deleted from the original report

Note: Reports must belong to the same reporter

POC
1. Create a Report with an attachment and file it to any team. Notice the reference_ID (Fxxxxx)
2. Create a new Report for any team and reference the ID via a POST in draft_Sync
 `POST /security/reports/draft_sync HTTP/1.1`
As soon as you do the POST Go to `the https://hackeone/security/reports/new`
You will see the reference_ID attachment attached.
3. Go to the report in 1. The reference_ID and attachment is deleted for the original report!

{F79192}


Hope it will be fixed!

Thanks!
